case_name: City of Nagpur Corporation v. Nagpur Corporation Employees Association

facts.text: Appeals numbered C.A. No. 1704 and 1937 of 1967 were filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. No. 1704 and 1937 of 1967. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals directed against judgment and order dated August 19, 1966 of Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Applications No. 853 and 941 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated ,August 19, 1966 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Applications No. 853 and 941 of 1965 respectively.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Dua, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by- Dua, J.-These two appeals by special leave

facts.text: Division Bench of Bombay High Court dismissed four applications under Art. 227 of the Constitution on August 19, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: judgment of a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court dated August 19, 1966 ,dismissing four applications under Art. 227 of the Constitution

facts.text: Applications arose out of orders made by Authority under Minimum Wages Act 1948 regarding claims by employees of City of Nagpur Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: C. As Nos. 1704 and 1937 of 1967  are directed against the, judgment of a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court dated August 19, 1966 ,dismissing four applic

facts.text: On July 13, 1964, Sitaram Madhorao, Chaukidar and 9 other employees of Octroi Department of Corporation filed application under s.20 of the Act in Court of Small Causes at Nagpur, the Authority.

anchor.surface_text: On July 13, 1964 Sitaram Madhorao, Chaukidar and 9 other employees of the Octroi Department of the Corporation filed an application under s. 20 of the Act in the Court of Small Causes at Nagpur,

facts.text: Application presented through General Secretary of Nagpur Corporation Employees Association, a registered trade union.

anchor.surface_text: which was the Authority. appointed under the .Act. The application was presented through the General Secretary of the Nagpur Corporation Employees Association which was a registered trade union.

facts.text: Applicants claimed overtime wages for period from 1-1-1964 to 30-6-1964, total Rs. 8670.18.

anchor.surface_text: That the applicants have been required to work overtime for 30, 65, 8 and 51 hours every week during the period from 1-1-1964 to 30-6-1964 and total claim are shown in the annexure. The total amount-

facts.text: Minimum wages notification issued by Government on 21-2-1951 for employment under Nagpur Corporation, minimum rate Re. 1-12 per day for eight hours.

anchor.surface_text: The Minimum wages numberification has been issued in respect of this industry by Government on 21-2-1951 and the minimum rates of wages are fixed 1-12 per day for eight hours.

facts.text: On June 26, 1964, T.R. Khante, Time-keeper and 13 other employees of Water Works Department filed application under s.20 through B.M. Mahale, General Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: Earlier on June 26, 1964 T. R. Khante, Time-keeper and 13 other employees of the Water Works Department of the Corporation had similarly applied under s. 20 of the Act through B. M. Mahale, General Secretary

facts.text: Water Works claimants worked overtime 8 hours every week from 1-8-63 to 31-1-64, total claim Rs. 1987.48.

anchor.surface_text: That the applicants have been required to work overtime for 8 hours every week during the period from 1-8-63 to 31-1-64 and the total claim are shown in the annexure. The total amount claimed is Rs. 1987.48.

facts.text: On November 10, 1964, preliminary objections by Corporation disallowed by Authority, applications directed to be tried on merits.

anchor.surface_text: On November 10, 1964 some preliminary objections raised by the Corporation were disallowed by the Authority and the applications were directed to be tried on the merits.

facts.text: On February 17, 1965, Authority made order on four issues.

anchor.surface_text: On February 17, 1965 the Authority made an order on the following four issues which arose out of the claims made by the employees

facts.text: Issue 1: Wireman held to be skilled worker, time-keeper and lineman semi-skilled, not unskilled.

anchor.surface_text: Under issue number 1 the wireman was held to be a skilled worker and the time-keeper and lineman, semi-skilled, disagreeing with their companytentions that they were unskilled workers.

facts.text: Issue 2: Second notification of 1956 only for unskilled labour in Nagpur Corporation; skilled/semi-skilled cannot claim under s.20.

anchor.surface_text: Under issue number 2 the Authority held that the second numberification of 1956 only provided for the minimum rates of wages of unskilled labour including casual labour in. the employment of the City of Nagpur Corporation.

facts.text: Applicants worked on Sundays held disentitled without provision under s.13(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The applicants mentioned in issue number 2 who had worked on weekly days of rest i.e., Sundays were accordingly held disentitled to claim wages for work done on those days in the absence of any provision made by the State Government under s. 13  1   c  of the Act.

facts.text: Authority dismissed all four applications with costs.

anchor.surface_text: All the four applications were accordingly dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Four special civil applications filed in Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench under Art.227.

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved by the order of the Authority four special civil applications were presented in the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench, under Art. 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court held 1956 notification applies to all employees, not confined to unskilled.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disagreed with the view of the Authority on the interpretation of the second numberification and held that the second numberification was intended to, apply to all employees

facts.text: High Court upheld ordinary rate in r.25 means ordinary minimum rate of wages.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, upheld the view of the Authority that ordinary rate of wages companytemplated by r. 25 means ordinary minimum rate of wages, companysidering this view to be in accordance with the view taken by the Bombay High Court

facts.text: Government fixed minimum wages by notification under s.5 on February 21, 1951 for unskilled labour including casual in scheduled employments including local authority.

anchor.surface_text: Minimum Wages were fixed by the Government by means of a numberification under s. 5 of the Act on February 21, 1951. According to this numberification the Government fixed minimum rates of wages for unskilled labour

facts.text: 1956 notification dated February 23, 1956 revised minimum rates in supersession of 1951 notification for employment under local authority.

anchor.surface_text: On February 23, 1956 the Government issued the following numberification fixing, revised minimum rates of wages in supersession of those fixed under the numberification of 1951

facts.text: Rule 25 of M.P. Minimum Wages Rules provides extra wages for overtime: double ordinary rate for non-agri scheduled employment.

anchor.surface_text: The point strenuously canvassed on behalf of the appellants. relates to the companystruction to be placed on r. 25 of the M. Minimum Wages Rules, 1951 made under s. 30 of the Act. That, rule provides

facts.text: Sunday declared day of rest, normal working hours 9 hours/day or 54 hours/week.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground between the parties that Sunday has been declared to be a day of rest and the numbermal working hours per day are 9 hours a day or 54 hours a week.

facts.text: Supreme Court held r.25 'ordinary rate of wages' means actual wages paid, not minimum wages.

anchor.surface_text: By using the phrase double the ordinary rate of wages the rule-making authority seems to us to have intended that the worker should be the recipient of double the remuneration which he, in fact, ordinarily receives

facts.text: 1956 notification confined to unskilled labour like 1951 notification.

anchor.surface_text: Coming number to the numberifications, in our view the numberification dated February 23, 1956 has to be read in the background of the numberification dated February 21, 1951

facts.text: Both appeals allowed, case remitted to Authority for fresh decision.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that both the appeals are allowed and the case is sent back to the Authority under the Minimum Wages Act for a fresh decision in accordance with law

anchor.surface_text: Let us first deal with this question. The Act which was enacted, in 1948 has its roots in the recommendation adopted by the International Labour Conference in 1928. The object of the Act as stated in the preamble is to provide for fixing minimum rates of wages

arguments.claim: Union of India v. B. Rathi and similar cases distinguished; s.14 does not require ordinary rate to mean minimum

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay High Court has no doubt held in Union of India v. B. Rathi 1  that ordinary rate of wages in r. 25 means the minimum rate for normal work fixed under the Act. The learned Judges sought support for this view from S. 14 of the Act

arguments.claim: 1956 notification confined to unskilled labour when read harmoniously with 1951 notification

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the notifications, in our view the notification dated February 23, 1956 has to be read in the background of the notification dated February 21, 1951

arguments.claim: Applicants are unskilled workers including time-keeper, wireman, lineman

anchor.surface_text: Under issue number 1 the wireman was held to be a skilled worker and the time-keeper and lineman, semi-skilled, disagreeing with their contentions that they were unskilled workers.

holdings.text: The 'ordinary rate of wages' in Rule 25 of the M.P. Minimum Wages Rules, 1951 means the actual rate of wages ordinarily received by the worker (basic wage plus allowances), and overtime must be paid at double that rate, not double the minimum rate fixed under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Let us first deal with this question. The Act which was enacted, in 1948 has its roots in the recommendation adopted by the International Labour Conference in 1928. The object of the Act as stated in the preamble is to provide for fixing minimum rates of wages

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual meaning of 'ordinary rate' reflects actual wages paid; purposive interpretation ensures real benefit, inducement for overtime, health protection; distinguishes Bombay HC precedent; harmonious with Act's object, industrial laws, Directive Principles.

holdings.text: The 1956 notification revising minimum wages is confined to unskilled labour (including casual), to be read in the background of the 1951 notification which explicitly applied only to unskilled labour, and does not extend to all employees.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the notifications, in our view the notification dated February 23, 1956 has to be read in the background of the notification dated February 21, 1951 with the result that the later notification must also be held to be confined to unskilled labour.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction requires reading 1956 notification as adjusting/revising rates within the scope of 1951 notification without expanding to skilled workers by omitting 'unskilled'.
